intro: Erigeron tricuneatus, commonly known as the three-angled fleabane, is a flowering plant native to North America. It is a member of the Asteraceae family, characterized by its composite flower heads that consist of both ray and disk flowers. The plant typically grows in open habitats such as meadows, prairies, and disturbed soils, and it is often found in the central and eastern United States. Its leaves are lance-shaped and hairy, while the stems are often branched and covered with fine hairs. The flowers bloom in late summer to early fall, producing a showy display that attracts pollinators like bees and butterflies.
